title: Lesson A2-1 Assessment: Introduction to Noun Cases

questions.question: How many cases are there in Georgian total?
questions.explanation: Georgian has 7 cases total. In this lesson, we learned the 3 most fundamental ones: Nominative, Dative, and Genitive.

questions.question: Which case is used for the subject of a sentence?
questions.explanation: Nominative case is used for the subject - the person or thing doing the action. This is the dictionary form of the noun.

questions.question: What ending typically marks Dative case?
questions.explanation: Dative case typically ends in -ს (s). For example: კატა (cat - Nominative) becomes კატას (cat - Dative).

questions.question: What ending typically marks Genitive case?
questions.explanation: Genitive case typically ends in -ის (is). For example: ბავშვი (child - Nominative) becomes ბავშვის (child's - Genitive).

questions.question: In the sentence 'მე ვხედავ კატას' (I see the cat), what case is კატას?
questions.explanation: კატას is in Dative case because it is the direct object - the thing receiving the action (being seen). Notice the -ს ending.

questions.question: Does Georgian have grammatical gender (like Spanish has el/la or French has le/la)?

options.text: Yes, just like Spanish or French
No, Georgian has no grammatical gender

questions.explanation: Georgian has no grammatical gender. Unlike languages like Spanish (el/la) or French (le/la), Georgian doesn't assign gender to nouns. This actually makes things simpler!

questions.question: Match the cases to their functions:
questions.explanation: Nominative marks subjects, Dative marks objects (both direct and indirect), and Genitive shows possession or relationships.
